speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: We will hear argument next in Vaden v. Discover Bank. Mr. Ortiz.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: That simply means that you can't bring an action in Federal court because the agreement says you can't. The agreement says you've got to arbitrate. So if you throw the agreement out save for such agreement, the question is whether or not you could then bring the action in Federal court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Mr. Ortiz, why isn't section 2 of the Arbitration Act sufficient to take care of the ouster doctrine, whatever may have been left of it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I'm not sure that I follow that, because it seems to me -- where did this doctrine of ouster come from? It came from the court. The courts said, no, we won't enforce arbitration agreements if it would oust us of jurisdiction. Why would a court reading section 2 not say, well, that rule never made any sense in the first place, so we're not going to follow it? It's not any rule that Congress has imposed on the courts.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That may have been the historic model. This was never a notion that Congress enforced on the courts. They imposed it on themselves. So my question remains why shouldn't the Court then say this agreement has been declared enforceable, the ouster doctrine didn't have much to recommend it in the beginning, but certainly not any more; we can change it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I'm just not getting the -- I have never understood this argument and I still don't understand it now. What is it in the text of section 2 that would seem to leave it inadequate to touch equity as well as law?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Exactly. And why, therefore, would anyone -- why would anyone be drawing distinctions as to how? It would be enforceable in any way that an agreement might appropriately be enforced in the courts of the United States at the time -- or any courts, for that matter, at the time the act was passed.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: It -- it made a categorical statement in section 2. Why did it need to be any clearer than that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, it could be, but why in the world would anyone draw that inference?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I have the same problem that Justice Souter does, especially since section 2 refers to equity. It says they will be irrevocable and enforceable, save upon such grounds as exist at law or in equity for the revocation of any contract. Obviously this -- this section was meant to apply to equitable actions. You wouldn't dismiss them in law for a -- a ground that only existed in equity?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I don't know. When it says they are enforceable and makes an exception only for grounds that enable revocation in law or in equity, I would -- I would think that the general command was meant to apply to both law and equity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I hate to interrupt you here, but would you explain why the words "save for such agreement" cut back on the jurisdiction? I didn't quite understand your point.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Doesn't it just instruct the court to decide whether, if there were no such agreements, would there be Federal jurisdiction in the underlying dispute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So in this case there would be.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: No, it's not the underlying bank debt, but it is an underlying dispute over which this Federal -- if you had brought your class action as an original case, there would have been Federal jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So then why doesn't the language read on this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The text says nothing about the ouster doctrine.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Rather than literally.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: This is a tough - - it's a tough sell. When you say "save for such agreement," which I agree with Justice Stevens seems to me you've put the agreement aside and then you say right away then you look at the agreement to see if there is Federal jurisdiction and only the agreement, not through that. So you're throwing it out and then you bring it right back in. It seems - -

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of the arbitration agreement?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Right. And I guess it's -- I mean, you say if it said save for the historic doctrine of ouster, then it would be easy to say, and then you look at the arbitration agreement. But it says "save for such agreement" and then you look at the agreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: You just -- you just used the words "arising out of the controversy." "The controversy" is used in several sections of the Arbitration Act, and "the controversy" in other contexts means the underlying dispute between the parties. "The controversy" is not over the enforcement of the arbitration agreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: In Moses H. Cone, didn't the court say that the controversy was the underlying dispute?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: But you do think - - you do think we should look through to determine diversity and the amount in question? In other words, not in the Federal-question context, but if it's diversity, you say we do look through the arbitration agreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Say that again. I didn't follow that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is that point argued in Moses -- Moses Cone? Was that point argued in that case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why wouldn't 1332 require complete diversity and require the court to assure itself of that anyway?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I thought you said it did have a look through, an automatic look through, itself.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: I see. I see. You are - - you are -- you are limiting it to the amount.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: I am not -- I mean just -- I have to be sure I follow. Why couldn't it require the same look through in a diversity case as it does in a Federal-question case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Complete diversity.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: What's wrong with that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Maybe it would. So what?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There is a dispute between people. You look at their underlying dispute, the underlying one, and you say: Is there diversity? What's the problem?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why -- why wouldn't you do just what I said, just what we started with? You take out the arbitration agreement, and then you look to see what this dispute is about. And if it's about something that happens to involve all people from one side in one State and from another State on the other side, there is jurisdiction. Why is that a problem? I don't understand.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Why?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: All right. So you define "look through" as -- under our hypothetical here as looking through to all people who might potentially be parties under this arbitration agreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I will think about that. I'm -- I'm -- I wasn't -- it wasn't clear to me that that was so.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Can I hold up just a second to make sure I understand it. You are saying that, let's say, Person A has an arbitration agreement that implicates Persons B and C. C is diverse, but B is not. They could decide to compel arbitration with respect to B and leave C out of it. But if you follow the look-through doctrine, you would say, well, the dispute is between A and B and C; and so you would be depriving A of their right to frame their own complaint in a way that doesn't create Federal jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: But that's not quite so, because the -- the action could proceed with just A and C, and then it -- it could come to a complete judgment as to them. In the look through for the -- the claims that are involved, the action couldn't possibly proceed without taking account of the pre-emption claim that the Federal -- the Federal claim. You couldn't -- you could decide the case completely in No. 1, the diversity case, but not in No. So there -- so there is a difference. It's true, you don't decide it completely as to all parties.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course, I suppose how that works depends on what the rules are about how you frame the dispute once you do look through. I mean, if there is a pending State suit between A and B, even though C may -- you could have sued C as well, I mean the judge can say, well, I am only going to look through to what the -- the actual litigation is; and if I look at that, that's not a Federal case. And -- and -- and so your position follows.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Yes, and what really leapt off the page at me in that opinion, he gets to the end, I think he basically presents your position and then he says: Thus, on my reading the relevant portion of section 4 could be rewritten this way. Well, I mean that to me is a confession of error if you have to rewrite the statute to get to your position.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Well, his rewriting doesn't look very much like section 4 to me.

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What about the fact that that was not included in the New Jersey statute, nor was it included in -- was it included in the Uniform Arbitration Act?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: What's the explanation for that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: I know. And you're saying New Jersey; it was, you know, a very complicated argument about the status of it. What about the Uniform Arbitration Act?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Mr. Phillips.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But that's the question that I have, Mr. Phillips. What is the underlying dispute between the parties? It seems to me that your look-through argument is look-through only halfway. That is, if you look -- if you consider the controversy, the suit that was brought in the State court, the controversy is here we have a customer who hasn't paid the amount charged. So we have a suit on a debt. Why isn't that the controversy? You have to make the counterclaim the controversy, which comes up only defensively. It wasn't brought as a lawsuit.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Who gets to frame - - who gets to frame the complaint? Normally if you're a party and you have a dispute that may implicate Federal law, you have control over the complaint. You don't have to have a -- you don't have to well plead it in a way that implicates a Federal question. You can go out of your way to do it in a way that does not implicate a Federal question; and therefore it would not be, you could not bring it in Federal court. Just as in the diversity example, you can specifically avoid suing people who would create diversity. But in your position the judge has to in his mind write a complaint and see whether there is jurisdiction or not; and how does the judge decide whether to sue diverse parties or not to sue diverse parties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But -- but she chose to assert it only defensively; and it's not a complaint - - the counterclaim if it had been brought as an independent action, everybody agrees qualifies for Federal jurisdiction. But the litigant who has this claim is asserting it only as a defense to a claim that you admit does not qualify for Federal jurisdiction.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But in the practical effect, what happens? Now you have asserted that you can enforce because of the counterclaim that asserts - - that arises under Federal law. But you say it's is not the same as removal because the underlying claim, your suit on the debt owed, remains in Federal -- State court; but what happens to that claim once you have this arbitration?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Phillips - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Clear up one thing for me. Is it correct, as Justice Ginsburg suggested, that the counterclaim was purely defensive? Didn't it ask for additional relief? The counterclaim, wasn't it a class action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So it was not merely an defense to the action, the State court action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I meant -- I didn't mean to say you couldn't get affirmative relief on a counterclaim. Of course you could. But this - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Chose not to - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- chose not to litigate the case, chose to -- well, I'm being sued, so I'm going to bring up this claim. It wasn't as an original matter.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: The controversy between the parties is the credit card company says, customer, you're in default $10,000; and the customer said, if that's so, then I have certain offsets because they charged me too much interest. How do you - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: -- how do you -- it's all part of the same controversy, isn't it?

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: What is the dispute? You say the dispute is not defined by what -- what has been brought in a complaint.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: But you -- from your argument, I would gather that a court would be able to imagine a counterclaim. Once it finds out, you know, what -- what -- what the principal complaint is about, the court could imagine that there would be a counterclaim for interest or for something else.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's very strange to decide Federal jurisdiction on the basis of -- of imagined - - imagined complaints.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: So the problem with his -- I mean with his interpretation, you don't have to imagine anything.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: You don't have to imagine complaints. You -- you don't have to invent litigation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: It's close to inconceivable to me that Congress wanted us to -- to construct litigation that is not yet in existence.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: -- answer that the litigation does exist.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: No, but your position is it doesn't have to exist. Had that litigation not been brought, had the motion to arbitrate been brought before a lawsuit was filed, that the court would still have to consider what is the dispute between the parties and what kind of complaints could that dispute have generated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: There would be nothing inappropriate about a State court entertaining that excessive interest claim, but applying Federal law to it. I mean the -- 1831(d) says that Federal law governs the interest - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Not state usury law. So you could have this case going on in State court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And the State court would be perfectly competent to apply the Federal law.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Well, why does it set aside? This is the thing I guess I don't understand about the case, and that is what is really driving your side, given the difficulties that I share with the Justices on my right and left here. And the -- the tacit assumption seems to be that you in fact are going to get shortchanged on your arbitration right if you have to bring your arbitration claim in a State court. And I don't see that.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: I know section 4 doesn't, but section 2 does.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: You can -- based on the Federal act, you can in State court claim your right to enforce the arbitration agreement.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Why don't you do it in the State court instead of going through these gymnastics?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Speaking of gymnastics, can I ask you if you had foreseen this problem, could you have brought a declaratory judgment action to establish that your Federal claim - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: -- controls this dispute and could you have then said that you wanted this arbitrated?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Why didn't you do that? Why are we here?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: I mean, could you still do that after this case?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So your theory -- I mean basically I think you concede that the other side has a point in sometimes it will be difficult to say what the dispute is precisely and, therefore, difficult to know if precisely this dispute does or does not -- one that you can get into Federal court on. For example, it hasn't even arisen. You know, there is no lawsuit. And I guess what would happen, what the judge should say is they should say to you you'd like to have this in Federal court, wouldn't you, this dispute? What's it about?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And once he says what's it about, both sides will say, well, basically it started off -- it's just about collecting some money from in-state parties. So that's not Federal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So that, you know, something could happen here. It could happen that they could decide they want to sue in a big class action and get huge amounts of money under usury laws of the State which don't exist, so they have to proceed under an FDIC reg, and then it could be Federal. And the judge might say to you: "What? You're just imagining." And that would be up to the judge.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: It's a kind of a defense.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But you'd say then it might be the case that it wouldn't be so hard to decide.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: A real suit. And - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: And in a real suit, there is a class action brought not just on behalf of the one you're trying to sue but on behalf of everybody, where they have to proceed under a Federal reg, and they are going to get a huge amount of money, and you say that's what we want arbitrated.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So this one is not so hard to figure out.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: There might be some that are.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: What's hard to figure out, you have, let's say, a franchisee, and you have a dispute with the franchisor. And the franchisee says it's an antitrust violation, and I'm going to sue you under the California antitrust law, and he does. And the Federal court says, we've looked through and says, well, you could have sued under the Federal antitrust law. And you -- yes, I could have; I deliberately didn't. And then they say, well, this is something that could have been brought in Federal court. And that really deprives a plaintiff of his right to frame his complaint as he sees fit.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Well, in his case, in the Chief Justice's case, wouldn't you say they don't get into court, probably don't because they are bringing this under a State law?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: No. But you just say, is the dispute one that could have been brought in Federal court?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: It's a violation of the Sherman Act.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Of course, it could be brought in Federal court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: That claim doesn't - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Let me get one fact.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Is the State court suit still pending?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: So there are two separate underlying actions.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But there could be nothing left for the State court to do after you have the arbitration. I mean, not that you arbitrate about interest due on a nonexistent debt. I mean, you have to have the two things together.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: I just can't envision a case where what you haven't effected is taking a case, a debt, simple debt, no diversity a State court case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: And you remove the State court from the picture and gotten it over into Federal court to order the arbitration and any follow-up to the arbitration. It just seems to me you have effected - - accomplished what you could not have accomplished by the -- by removal, which you admit that you can't remove on the basis of a counterclaim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: That's what worries me. That's what worries me. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: If we accept your theory, this is the easiest case, what about the hard cases that are further down the line?

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But you could have asked for that in the State court as well, and - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SOUTER
speakers.text: Then bring that up here on appeal from the State court.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You don't have any trouble. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: It's not really -- of getting constants from Federal judges; the arbitrators can decide this question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: The arbitrator might decide there is no preemption.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: May I ask this, I haven't reread the Moses Cone case, but is your adversary correct in saying that there would have been no jurisdiction in that case it we followed your view?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Because the arbitrator was not of diverse citizenship from the other parties?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: But -- if, in fact, were a nondiverse party in the Moses Cohen, there should have been no jurisdiction?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Is this right? I'm asking if it may sound favorable to you, then I'll get a good response in rebuttal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If you read it the other way -- if you read it the other way, the way the Petitioners want to read it, then is this so or not? That then you look to see if there is Federal jurisdiction of the arbitration agreement; is that right?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Yes, under their interpretation.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So, what you could have is you could have two parties sign an arbitration agreement that lasts for a year that governs all disputes between them, and one is from Vermont; the other from California.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So there is jurisdiction. And all the disputes happen to involve just pure matters of -- that never could come into Federal court. I mean there are such matters you could argue about.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: But nevertheless, we have a Federal court issuing this injunction, under their theory.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Assuming they are right.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Oh, I see. The arbitration agreement has to meet the amount in controversy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: All right. So then probably no arbitration agreement in itself meets the amount.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: So if you didn't look through, then this would apply to nothing?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: If the arbitration - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: The arbitration agreement has to -- they talk about the arbitration agreement, then you could have really important Federal questions in substantive issues - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: -- that couldn't come in because the arbitration agreement doesn't? Or you could have State questions that would suddenly come in because the arbitration agreement does. The arbitration -- but now you're saying, well, that second case is never going to arise.

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Probably not, because no arbitration agreement has -- so then it becomes a nullity of the statute?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: Except to overcome the ouster. Okay. We've got your side of it. (Laughter.)

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Well, it makes a nullity of it, except that it gets into the Federal court the decision on the arbitration agreement, which was the object of this stuff, whatever -- whatever the underlying claim is, whether it's a Federal claim or not. As I understood the purpose of the Arbitration Act, it was to make sure that arbitration was -- was honored not just in Federal cases but in State cases as well. And it's entirely compatible with that, that sometimes a Federal court will -- will direct arbitration in a case this involves an underlying controversy that's purely non-Federal.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Why isn't it proper to look to see -- the party who wants arbitration has a dispute; the dispute is we are owed money by the debtor. Why shouldn't the court say, well, we'll see what your case is about; if your case would qualify for Federal jurisdiction, fine. But we are not going to look to see what the defendants cases is or might be. We'll just look at your case and that's how we will define the controversy.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: But then you'll have not only a hypothetical claim, because nothing has been brought, but an hypothetical answer by way of counterclaim to that claim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: So you would come into the court and say there is no suit going on anywhere, but if we were to bring this suit in State court, the defendant could have brought this Federal counterclaim? That's a lot of hypothesis.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: Mr. Phillips, the answer to a better hypothetical is what if there had been no original collection action but they had brought such an action.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: That's the case you're really saying. You're saying that is like this case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: And Justice Ginsburg is suggesting it's not, because it happens to arise out of a different -- quite different dispute.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: Excuse me - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: As I understand your opponent, they would agree there was no jurisdiction even in that case.

speakers.name: JUSTICE GINSBURG
speakers.text: What do you do with the assertion that sections 9 through 11 are not in sync with your view, because they would not give you -- you could go in and -- to compel arbitration but once the arbitration was award -- an award was made, you would not have access to the Federal courts to enforce the award?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: But the Petitioner says you never clearly clarify the particular Federal on which the jurisdiction rests on this case. What -- can you clarify that?

speakers.name: JUSTICE ALITO
speakers.text: Section 4 creates the Federal - -

speakers.name: JUSTICE SCALIA
speakers.text: Why -- why can't you have sort of modified look, through like a modified limited hangout or whatever it was? That is to say, you can look through for the purpose of determining whether the arbitration agreement raises a Federal question. But that doesn't mean you have to look through to determine whether the underlying controversy raises a Federal question.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: Is the Petitioner's -- I'm sorry I didn't get a chance to ask the Petitioner -- is the Petitioner's argument for a limited look through compromised in any way by the Beneficial Bank case which allows removal if there is a Federal defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: That's of course in the context of a defense, as opposed to a counterclaim.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, Mr. Phillips. Mr. Ortiz, you have three minutes remaining.

speakers.name: JUSTICE KENNEDY
speakers.text: What about a Federal defense?

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: That isn't quite true, because here there is a definition in the Federal claim in your counterclaim.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: There is a definition of the controversy in your counterclaim and in their response.

speakers.name: JUSTICE STEVENS
speakers.text: You're suggesting that every credit card debtor would have a class action?

speakers.name: JUSTICE BREYER
speakers.text: That's your view, but I mean believe me, I think I can keep that problem under control. That was your original point. I see the point, it's going to spread too far; you'd have to have some rules that cabin it. Assume I got that under control; maybe I don't. This is a case of "well, his brother was worse." What do you want to say about the criticisms of the horrible things that happen if we adopt your position?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: I'm sorry, what do you mean would still be covered?

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Which would still be in Federal court.

speakers.name: CHIEF JUSTICE ROBERTS
speakers.text: Thank you, counsel. The case is submitted.
